reviewText: I have a soft spot for the original Warlock in spite of its many failings (poor AI, poor play balance and numerous bugs). But I cannot recommend this new release.  It is basically window dressing on the old game without addressing any of its faults.  Aside from the revamped spell research, nothing that couldn't be provided in DLC. Oh it's got more, more pictures, more units and two new races. If you don't mind paying $30 (or $40) for your DLC then hop on board.  But if you were looking to address the fundamental issues (above) then don't waste your time and money.\n\nThere is actually one group I can recommend it to and that is those that liked the Armaggedon DLC.  They didn't fix the pathing or the horrible NPC AI. (I think the monster AI got some tweaks) But their solution to those looking for a challenge is to introduce a whole slew of tough Spirit damage dealing monsters and unload wave after wave of monster spawns; very much in the spirit of Armaggedon.  The larger your territory the larger your clean-up issues.  As a plus you don't have to worry about your actual economy since the frequent spawns will keep you swimming in gold and mana.

Edit: You can disable the city limit at the startup. For some reason I thought it was included in my original review, I was mistaken. Disabling it does make the experience a lot more like the first game and more fun in my eyes. Also tried to fix some spelling errors – no excuses for those.

I wish I could recommend Warlock 2. I really liked the first game as a cheap, fun little Civ clone with a bigger focus on combat. I thought number 2 would address some of my complaints about the first game or at least change things up. But what I didn't like about Warlock 1 remains and also has some new annoyances: bare-bones diplomacy system, random AI opponent decisions (really alliances don't matter - you'll end up warring and clashing with everyone), limiting how many perks you can give to units, enemies spawning inside your territory at random times (especially when it decides to create enemies FAR too powerful you to deal with), random quest spawning that creates enemies that you need to fight, even if you refuse those quests...the list sadly goes on.

And while I understand the new Unrest rules and city limit, Warlock pretty much thrived on expanding and creating more and more cities and the Unrest system pretty much makes it so you need to play it small. And considering how massive some of the worlds can be you'll run out of effective cities really quickly. That means you need to convert old cities into special cities: free cities (like Civ puppet cities, only they only generate an insignificant amount of gold, fortress cities (which is pretty much a range 3 tower) or religious cities (which give a small amount on mana and improve relations with the chosen god). Maybe if people don’t like managing large amounts of cities they'll enjoy this focus but for me it just didn't work.

I did have some fun with Warlock 2. In the 70 hours I put into it I really liked going through portals and discovering new worlds in the Exiled mode. But honestly if you need a fantasy 4X game go with Civ 5 (with some of the fantasy mods), Fallen Enchantress and Warlock 1. If you do want to play 2, I recommend a really big steam sale.

reviewText:
Warlock 2 is a truly fantastic game, despite what some of these reviews may say. If you're a lover of 4X strategy games and fantasy lore, get this game -- you won't be sorry.

One of the reasons this game has so many harsh ratings is because it can be a little buggy. But on the right system (Windows 7, 8 and 10 all work well), it's a ton of fun and you'll encounter few bugs. I can safely say this after 2000+ hours of game play.

However, the Linux and Mac versions do not work. The developers were forced to abandon the game before they were fixed, so avoid this game if you're using one of those OS's.


PROS
------

There are more pros than I have time to list for this game, but here are the ones that stick out the most:

- Tons of flavorful units
- Varied races
- Simple but highly strategic combat system
- Wide variety of fantasy resources
- Interesting spells
- Great game modes (Sandbox is a single big map with subworlds; Battle for Outplanes is on shard" worlds that offers an entirely different experience and is probably more beginner-friendly)
- Challenging campaign modes
- Rich and comical lore
- Excellent replay value
- Tons of fun -- one of the best games I've ever played (and I've played A LOT of games over the years)


CONS
------

BUGS

There are a few subborn bugs and the developers are no longer able to work on the title to fix them. On Windows
date: none of the bugs are truly game-breaking.\n\nTo give you an idea
recommended:
roughly 1 in 20 games I've played have crashed at some point. (Games are usually 20+ hours long.) The good news is that you can usually "correct" a game-crash bug by loading an autosave from just a turn or two prior and doing your turn a little differently.

Note that there are also a few mods that fix a number of minor bugs -- Renaissance Mod fixes many of them.


SUBPAR AI

As a beginner
hoursPlayed: the AI seems quite strong. But once you know what you're doing
voteText: the AI is lackluster and you'll catch it making some bone-headed moves
helpfulPercent: even on the most difficult setting.\n\nAgain
votesHelpful: a few mods exist that have improved the AI -- Legendary Mode AI is one and Renaissance Mod is another. The AI still makes the occasional poor move
votesTotal:
but the games themselves are much more challenging with either of these mods.


NOT FOR LINUX / MAC

Despite what the description says
votesFunny:
users agree that the game is not in a playable state for Linux and Mac users.


DIFFERENCES BETWEEN WARLOCK 1
---------------------------------------

The first Warlock was widely criticized on two counts:

1) It looked like a Civ 5 clone. True
commentsCount: it does have a very similar feel to the UI in Civ 5
column16: and it has retained this feel for the sequel. But the gameplay is quite different than a Civ title
column17: with only slight similarities.\n\n2) The game lacked strategic depth. To win
column18: all you really needed to do was to "city spam" your way to victory. There was no downside for having multiple cities
column19:
making most games feel like a race to see who could expand the fastest.

You could also "perk" (buff) as many units as you wanted just by capturing a single resource tile.

Warlock 2
column21:
changed both of these things for the better by adding some much-needed limitations.


GREATER LIMITATIONS

Some people who enjoyed the freedom Warlock 1 granted with regards to city spamming and limitless unit perks are likely to be turned off by the sequel. I know I was... until I learned how to "replay" the game.

In fact
column22: fans of the first title pushed back so hard on the city limit that the developers even added the ability to turn this off when you create a new game. But just as the developers noted that disabling the city limit is "not recommended
column23:
I will echo the same. The gameplay is so much richer with some scarcity and consequences for overextending -- just as it is in the best 4X games.


MORE STRATEGIC DEPTH

As I learned to play with the newly laid out limitations on number of cities and availablity of perks, along with the new unrest system, I discovered that the developers really did know what they were doing. The game has TONS more strategic depth with these limitations in place. So again -- take some of these negative reviews with a grain of salt.

The developers really did a lot to improve the game with these simple changes. When people say Warlock 2 is just a clone of Warlock 1, they are sorely mistaken.


MUCH IMPROVED RESEARCH TREE

In Warlock 1, researching spells is entirely random. When it's time to research a new spell, you're given a small selection of random spells and are able to chose one.

The sequel offers an actual research tree, with clearly laid out paths to acquire new spells. This gives you the ability to navigate the tree and see all the spells, allowing you to strategically chose your preferred research path. Many players consider this the best improvement over the original.


SUMMARY
-----------

Aside from World of Warcraft, I don't think I've ever spent so much time playing (and enjoying) a game.

Is Warlock 2 perfect?

No.

The cons I described above should be fair warning to those who are concerned about getting this game.

Is Warlock 2 worth your time and money?

YES. Absolutely.

Sure, It does have some imperfections -- many of which I've managed to correct myself in my own popular mod for the game, Renaissance Mod:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=493257789
Note that Renaissance adds loads of fun new content to the game, too.


TL;DR - If you're running Windows and you love fantasy and 4X games, get this game and the DLC -- especially if it's on sale. You'll be doing yourself a disservice not to give it a try.

If it was as bad as some of these other reviews would have you believe, there wouldn't be such a loyal fanbase for the game.

For the person who is NOT familiar with Warlock:

Warlock is easily comparable to Civilization or any other turn-based strategy games (4k). Think Civ 4 with magic instead of nukes, werewolves instead of tanks, and heroes that kill everything. The only real difference is that YOU have the power. Any single creature on the map is ultimately powerless against the almighty Great Mage (you). They are unable to attack you directly, leaving you to cast hellfire and lay waste to your enemies. However, you are not alone. Others like you have taken up their roles as leaders. It is a strategy game in which the king himself is not useless and everything is your pawn. It has diverse abilities for the Great mage. Abilities such as healing, fireball, frost nova, and even ones that allow you to modify tiles around you. Using this to your advantage you are to beat the other mages to a bloody pulp with your wit and charm... OR JUST RAMPAGE THROUGH EVERYTHING WITH AN OP ARMY OF GIANT HELIAN WEREWOLVES... or is that just me....
Anyway, interactions with other mages can either lead you towards joint prosperity or a WAR. Random occurances can just as easily wipe out a city as any of your enemies. Oh, all your troops on the front lines? Have two annoying dragons harrass your Capital. It's alright. I'm sure you'll survive...

Gods are important, and thus your relation to them can alter the tides of battle in your favor. They can provide you with epic level units or give you a spell that can obliterate your enemy. With many Gods to choose from you will learn who suits your playstyle very easily.

There are several worlds that coincide with one another. These worlds are split up and can be navigated between via portals. There are several miniature locations all set around different biomes and then the main land. Ardiania. Fun place. Green grass, blue water, giant serpent monsters, massive spiders... You know, epic vacation level stuff. Beautiful terrain where everything seems to want to kill you. Why did you ever leave?


TL;DR
Warlock is one of those games you can spend hours at a time and never get bored. It never slows down and always has you focused on complete anihilation of your foes, or desperate survival from hordes of enemy forces. Every turn is something new. If the game slows down, it'll throw a personal quest at you, sometimes a band of misfits, maybe an elemental, or sometimes an enemy epic level creature that can eat a city in one turn.Anything Goes. It's mostly unexpected and on the harder difficulties any wrong step means certain death. Are you up for the challenge?

UI is the same as Warlock 1, however, it has multiple modes, new races, new units, an actual storyline, and the best part? It is mod compatible, something the community of Warlock: Master of the Arcane asked for, for a long long time.

Updated: The Paradox forums indicate no further patching will be done on the Mac or Linux versions of this game:

http://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/index.php?threads/new-osx-linux-patch-2-2-203-live-on-beta-branch.818297/#post-19299159

The game remains broken in a number of key ways on these platforms and should not be purchased. Extremely shabby practice.

Original review:

This game seems to be very solid mechanically. I wish that what buildings were available was tied to a tech tree of some kind, but that's a minor complaint. What sticks out is that Warlock II solves the late game micro Hell of most 4X games without sacrificing early and mid expansion and development play by making it prudent to convert your cities into automated gold or mana or piety batteries. I think this is a brilliant design decision. Compare it to Civ V BNW. In BNW, hard nerfs to science left four to six cities optimal for most of the game, which means that decisions about city placement and development are kind of limited in scope. By mid game these cities will be strong enough to each build everything useful, and because there are so few multiplicative national or great wonders there's little incentive to specialize. Here, because you're constantly expanding outwards and throwing your initial core cities onto automated gold production, you have all kinds of opportunites to specialize your new settlements according to the local terrain and to make decisions about whether to maintain a well-built research city that puts you over your limit and will never be strategically useful as a unit production center.

So while I think this is one of the most ingenious design decisions I've seen in a strategy game lately, I can't recommend this game. First, there are major problems with the AI. I don't especially mind this because the game's emphasis seems to be on using your empire as an engine to reach and generate units powerful enough to defeat powerful NPC units rather than on direct competition with AI empires, but it bears mentioning that the enemy empire AI basically can't play the game.

The most major issue, though, is the huge array of bugs on the Mac and Linux ports. Being a huge Civilization fan, I was very happy to find out about another series that is very very similar in gameplay style - but not that similar so is different having it's own theme.

Having played all the Civ games it was very easy to jump straight into this,  for those new to this genre you should play the tutorial and read a little online tips and tricks,  to get you off to a smooth start.

You build up your own civilization, you create soldiers to defend and attack, pioneers to found new cities, you construct buildings to help your city grow and research spells to help you advance.

There are many modes to choose from, you can play relaxed to impossible. You can custom design your starting lands which also come in a few flavours,  exiled, sandbox and one other - you choose your Mage (leader) and how many Mages you compete against.

Your armies are supplement by arriving lords, whom you can equip with special artifacts. They are very powerful fighting units-  and wise to keep them alive as long as possible.

You move your units and research/construct in turns- you make your moves and then the opposition make theirs and it is your turn again.
There are many enemies to deal with, not just from the Mages civ-  many creatures that spawn themselves for you to battle as you discover new lands.

It is not a quick game- you need to spend a lot of time just to play through one full game, but it is addictive and easy to keep having that one more turn before you log out!  It is very interesting and quite fun.

A couple of annoyances like always having to give your units orders each turn-  unless i am missing something there.

There is a  multiplayer option too.

i rate this game 8/10 and highly recommend it for strategy game lovers.

I feel compelled to write a review on Warlock 2 because I've notices quite a few negative reviews.  As someone who has never played the first Warlock I absolutely highly recommend this version for fans of the 4x genre.  The main gripe I've read in reviews about this game is that it is so much like the first rendition of the game. I've found that different heroes are available for hire dependingn on my Factions Race.  I was the undead and I had the option of hiring a Giant Ogre. The technology, city building, and battles all play out similarly to Civ 5 with the exception of the ability to cast spells (And there are a lot of spells).  There are also a ton of units, and buildings etc.  The variety is almost overwhelming at times (But in a good way).

Warlock 2 has all the pros of Civ 5 but with some added improvements as previously mentioned.  I don't have a single con for this game!  Not a one!!!

With that being said, I haven't touched on the best feature of the game yet.  The ability to mod anything and EVERYTHING!  You want a new Faction?  Do it!  You want new spells?  Do it!  You even want new races or units?  Do it!  New artefacts, Mages, and even buildings?  Yup, you can do that too!  You can even upload your own photos into the game to have whatever picture of your new Mage and/or Faction you may like!  It's absolutely incredible and simple to do!  I can actually see myself spending more time in the mods than the actual game lol.  However, if the mods aren't for you, the game in itself and the gameplay is great within itself.

Highly highly recommend for any fan of the genre.

Even though this game tries to improve on the previous edition with more races, more features, and even some better systems, it also creates other problems that overshadow the improvements. Being less fun would be ok if this game was different from the original... it's not. Alot of the art and models are literally the same, the gameplay is almost identically, even entire tech trees for races remain the same. This game feels like a bunch of mods/dlc added to the old game instead of a new game. So since its not different and is worse, just get Warlock: Master of the Arcane.

First, what the game got right, because credit where credit is due:
Spell research is much improved over the previous edition. You pick and plan your spell research instead of being given 5 random options to pick from.

Monster lair spawn rate can be adjusted to be less annoying in the late game, or you can have more of it if that's what your into.

Some of the additional races, spells, perks, and resources add some complexity and are interesting.
Temples allow you to gain reputation with specific gods, even in early/mid game.

Too many strong neutral monsters are found everywhere. You're early game, the most crucial part of any run, depends almost entirely on whether you can find city locations away from strong mobs. reviewText: I *REALLY* wanted to like this game... I really did -- but the bottom line is that it is convoluted and stupid. Close up, the game is AWESOME. Lots of different units, spells, monsters... Plenty of everything you'd expect and desire in a game like this. Why does it suck? I'll give you some examples -- The campaign world is a series of linked world-shards, or planes, or whatever -- these are connected by gates. It may take several turns for a unit to travel from one connected plane to the next much less to a plane several links away. Your economy cannot support large stacks of units for every city you have on every plane -- so the bulk of your army has to be at the forefront of your campaign. However, no matter how domesticated the planes you conquer become, wild monsters always pop up there. You're forced to summon or send back units to places you've conquered over and over again. It also gets confusing which planes are connected where, and it just seems there should be an easier way to move around and control things. Also, city development is based on a flowchart where to build more sophisticated buildings you must have prerequisite buildings -- this is a common element in this genre of game. HOWEVER, despite this being done right in almost every other game where this is an element, it manages to somehow be opaque in this game what structures a city should have to enable you to build higher tier buildings -- you can either constantly refer to the flow chart button (annoying, and sometimes doesn't scroll anyway) or try to figure it out which the tutorial itself says is just going to lead to frustration and wasted effort. Why not have the city building be done ON THE FLOWCHART, then? Beats the bloody hell out of me. Instead you're wondering why one city you have can only build a million craftsman districts while another one can have a bank and a mint in it... is it because the other city in question has a granary? WHY THE HELL SHOULD THAT MATTER, and if it does why isn't it more obvious!? It's so sad that this game sags under it's weight like it does, because there is plenty to recommend it if such key aspects didn't suck.

reviewText:
Warlock 2 does, at least in my humble opinion, exactly what a good sequel should do.  There are no sweeping changes here, there are no completely different mechanics, there's no arbitrary new mini-game that fundamentally alters how you play.  Warlock 2 takes all of what made the original fun and polishes it, adds to it, develops, evolves and improves.  City and army building has been greatly improved with more transparency of 'tech trees', unit-improvement resources are now handled better and spell research is leaps and bounds better, with direct and clear choices offered to the player at each step of the way.

While many of the art and sound assets  are direct from the first iteration, everything seems just a little more nicely rendered, a little more well built and just, well, better.  The UI is clearer, there is far more help available in-game and everything seems more to-hand than the original did.  With the new game mode and the editor, the wider selection of races and units, there's a lot of content to explore and consume before the well runs dry.

Overall, this game is a superb example of what happens when you build a sequel not by reaching for new faddish quirks, by trying to cater to the lowest common denominator or by bloating the game up with reams of pointless minutiae that require advanced statistics and spreadsheets to manage, but by playing the game and understanding that the game was already fundamentally good and simply tweaking and polishing and improving every point.

If you liked the original, you will love Warlock 2: The Exiled.  If you didn't like the original, there's a very good chance that whatever put you off has been addressed and improved in this new edition.

Did you enjoy Warlock 1 and wish you had a bigger sandbox with more toys, but the same dumb AI to play against?

If your answer is yes, then this game is for you.

Here's an excerpt from my full review:

Is Warlock 2 a sequel? Is it a reboot? Is it both? Is there even a difference?  I have followed the game online for months and there is no general consensus. I could not form my own opinion until the game was ported to OSX in late October ’14. Now I’m finally going to set my sights on Ardania. I have a score to settle. I seek revenge. I’m going to wipe out the other great expats of Ardania, and seek control. But first, I have to fight the non-stop hordes of monsters that spawn everywhere. I have a schizophrenic AI to tame, it’s time to break out my wizard hat. Let’s begin.

TL;DR: If you wanted a true sequel to the surprise that was Warlock 1, you’ll be very disappointed. At best, Warlock 2 is a polished Warlock 1 with a bit more content added. Granted, it was ported to MAC, but in it’s current state it is a broken mess. Warlock 2 is probably only worth buying on sale at a deep discount.

You might like this game if:

You’ve always wanted to play a fantasy 4X game that mirrors a lot of what Civilization 5 does but with an even more neurotic AI.
You like having a plethora of choices with faction units and don’t mind that they don’t look graphically up-to-date.
You like the idea of one unit per tile and possibly prefer it over the “stack of doom”.
You just want more of the same Warlock, with some minor upgrades and additions.

You might NOT like this game if:

You like having meaningful diplomacy. None to be had here.
You like your AI opponents to give you a challenge in single player.

Paradox took Warlock: Masters of the Arcane, slapped a novelty glasses-and-mustache disguise on it, and called it Warlock 2.

reviewText:
The problem with Warlock 2 is not that it's a bad game; rather, it doesn't add enough to justify the 'sequel' tag and $30 price point.  Exiled mode is merely a focused string of 'pocket dimensions' (that already existed in the first game) in a campaign format -- no more innovation than the Armageddon mode for Warlock 1.  The other improvements and additions are arguably ones that should have been included in a patch or, at most, a $10 DLC.  Unrest is the only truly new mechanic and its implementation is primarily intended to cap the number of cities you can build.  This ultimately has little bearing on the game as you can win on even the hardest difficulty with a few lords and a couple of complimentary units.

The Great Mage edition for $50 is particularly laughable as it merely adds a few lords I've never even seen in 30+ hours of play, a few spells I've never bothered to cast, and a dragon mage hero that doubles as a capital -- the latter being the only one I'd recommend buying separately for a couple of bucks.  The other extras are a bunch of out-of-game materials most people won't listen to/read.

Edited: And now in the recent patch they've added an in-game store selling things like the privilege of starting on a certain plane/shard for $3.  Warlock 1's Armageddon DLC cost the same and added a new mode.  The Elf DLC added a new race for the same price.  Paradox is definitely on the decline with all these cash grabs.

reviewText:
Do not buy this game!

On paper this is pretty much Warlock 1 with a few additions which mostly amounts to 2 extra races (which feel samey), a few extra spells (along with a new research system), as well as a new playing mode where you start of in other planes of existance. In fact those are where the game shines the most as the plane to plane gameplay is actually quite interesting and some of the random events really shake up the gameplay and can make even raising your army interesting as the conditions of the universe change on you.

The issue though is that all the problems with the first game rather persist. The game has the same glitches including a crash bug that still goes unfixed from Warlock 1, the same imbalances, an unbalanced mage creation system, poor braindead AI, Overpowered heros, useless ordinary units (with exceptions).

Then there are the problems unique to this game. The planes never feel fully fleshed out with their own resources, the races barely take advantage of the planes, the quest system will constantly bar you from progress and ask you to either defeat an excessively tough enemy that can span you hundreds of turns to defeat or require you to pony up resources obscene to collect. Then there are some planes that are neigh on impossible to explore. As well while the events are quite interesting a lot of them only serve to harass you, don't be surprised if the game just decides a volcano would look rather nice next to your capital.

Finally these features don't mesh well with eachother, for example the mage creation system doesn't take into account the new research tree.

Ultimately this is a stand alone expansion of Warlock 1. Which would be fine but they just didn't care to put the time and attention that this game needed to shine. It needed to be balanced better, with more features to fill out those planes, A good AI, As well as an overhaul to the random events and quests. In spite of all the effort they clearly put into this game, it still somehow feels like a cheap cash in.

reviewText:
Not terribly impressed with this title.

Plays like civ with magic. I was hoping to get a tast of old-school Master of Mgic, and this was a temporary fix. It's different enough from Civ to be fun and refreshing, but the game mechanics made it tedious in mid to late game.

Pros:
- Challenging - The wrong move could easily cost you a veteran hero. You learn to wander off into new worlds only with expendible troops, etc. You will lose troops. You will lose cities. The rise and fall is exciting.
- Different - Tile types and heros were different - you can build mana farms instead of farms. Perks provided by certain improvements were really interesting and fun.
- Variety - The tech trees for different civilizations were well-thought out and different enough to force you into a different strategy for each.

Cons:
- Very few options with excess mana. Can't increase your casting power, so you just accumulate excess mana if your economy is mana-focused. It's frustrating.
- Excess food means NOTHING. You have a minimum food for population and troops eat (a little) food, but towns increase in size at a fixed rate, so unless your people are starving, there's no benefit to extra food. Yes, excess is converted to cash, but if I needed cash, I'd build cash buildings.
- The economy revolves around money. There's a cap on how much mana you can realistically spend, and excess food is converted to cash, so you quickly learn that building cash is the only really valuable resource. This removes a lot of strategy and the benefits of any variety in the different races.
- Random events are devasating and often change the landscape, affecting the bonuses of carefully placed town improvements. They sometimes take out town population, which might have taken 30 turns to increase by 1 (at a fixed rate), leaving your economy in shambles with no way to recover for another 30+ turns: enough to cost you the game.

This game seemed promising, but in the end was just annoying. This game is being uninstalled.

reviewText:
My favorite 4X.  I like that the different campaigns are very different.  You can play a conquer your neighbors game like any other, on either a series of worlds or on a large world with the other worlds attached as possible, though not necessary places to explore; or you can compete to be the first to finish a series of increasingly difficult quests in what maybe shouldn't be the default game mode;  or if you have the expansion you can play against a single strong opponent who appears in the middle of your civilization, nagas this time rather than dremers as in the first game.  I like that this final mode encourages you to work together with your opponents whether they are computer players or human players, and I like that computer allies really will help you.  This is something very lacking in really all the other 4X games, where it is just a fight for supremacy.

The other thing that sets this game appart is the focus on tactical combat and exploration rather than civilization building or roleplaying (as in the Age of Wonders or HOMM series).  I like this. You start off right away with an army and your army grows just as much as you want it to, as you can build units at the same time as buildings in your cities.  (a bizarre restriction in the Civ games and in the Endless games)  There are so many different types of neutral units that hide great rewards in their spawn points.  Much of the early game is just plain survival, and it's a lot of fun.  It never seems like you've explored everything.  Even after 100s of hours that I've spent in both Warlock 1 and 2 combined.  In multiplayer turns are turn-based rather than simultaneous, but as everything happens on the main map, and you can watch your allies, things don't seem as boring as HOMM (which I would never play multiplayer).

I really am liking Endless Space and Endless Legend as well, those really have a lot to discover, but this has a pick up and play quality and a, I must play just a few more turns, quality that keeps me playing this even when those are available.  I suppose I would play those when I want something more serious, and this when I want something fun, while the old standards of Civ and HOMM are really starting to feel more OLD than standard in their current iterations.

Warlock 2 is basically the samge game Warlock 1 was. A very good fantasy CIV-like game. The other good one is Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes, but although the games cover same niche, they are drastically different from each other.

In here most things are similiar to CIV5, besides maybe magic system. Also units level ups and upgrades seem more important here. Beyond that, it is all about building more and more towns, units and reasearch (which kind of limits the growth here, unlike Warlock 1).

It is pleasing to expand using specialized cities, gain resources and improve your several units, but it is tedious even on medium maps and with just 2 enemies, when they start to spam units and towns on every possible hex of land. Despite being speed up, enemy turns take long (many weak units) and I decided on war with them even if they want to ally, just so I don't have to watch all their units move.

The shard-like lands, which are connected with gates seem to contain the above problem a little bit (the idea of shards with teleporters itself is ripped of from Allods/Rage of Mages :P). This makes it easier to for the player to just block off the enemy waves and slowly rip them apart.

The addition of (heavily overpriced?) Lords that you can recruit adds a bit to the game as well.

Although the game is a definite improvement and it really plays nice, sometimes it just feels like a big (but not huge) DLC to the core game.

Is it worth it?

If you never played any Warlock games but like strategy games and fantasy settings: YES!

If you tried Warlock 1 and did not like it too much: NO!

reviewText:
I am a big fan of Warlock: Master of the Arcane and I had great expectations for The Exiled. I can`t deny I am frustrated by some of the changes they made to this sequel. My biggest complaint goes to the addition of city unrest, which could be an attempt to add some more strategy depth by slowing down the conquest pace and forcing you to balance city specialization. You are now limited to a set number of cities until you research spells that increase the cap or transform conquered cities in Fortresses or Free Towns, which don`t add up to the limit, but also prevent you from constructing buildings and units. In my oppinion, this is a huge step back, for one of the features I liked most in Warlock was its total focus on war. No meddling with happiness or similar things. Conquer the nearest city and go on to the next. If I wanted a Civ-like game, I'd play Civ V.

The graphics didn't change much, although you can perceive some minor improvements. There are new units, spells and a campaign mode that gives you  chance to play the game in a different scenario-based way.

All in all, Warlock 2 is a good game, bringing you more of the same you love, but fans of the original might not like the change in pace. If you are new to the series and want a fast and furious game, focusing on battles with fantasy units and monsters, try Warlock: Master of the Arcane first. If you've played the first and is looking for the same gameplay experience, think again if you can cope with the lash on your warmongering appetite.

reviewText:
TL;DR:  warlock 2 is a great game, and IMO improves upon Warlock 1 and is worth the $30 price.

i understand the criticism that this game seems more like an expansion than a sequel.  IMO, whichever side of the fence you are on.. its a subjective opinion... and honestly, if you feel that way, i totally get it.

here's how i look at it though..

one:  you are paying the same price you would for most stand alone expansions.

for $30 you get the standard edition, and you get everything you need minus the bonus content, which is bonus content if you want it.  i dont consider anything in the Great Mage edition a must have.

thus, you are essentially getting the full game for $30.  the price seems pretty reasonable to me - even if we are saying this is just an expansion.

two - Exiled Mode:

first, its unique.  instead of one large map where you go out adventuring, collecting stuff, building your empire, conquering other civilizations,  all on a single plane..  you have a ton of smaller maps which you access by opening portals.. each with their own unique flavor to them, and you STILL have the adventuring, loot finding, conquering, etc.

and what makes things even more unique is that each of the maps have a different element effect.  one will be undead, one will be lava lands, one will be winter/frost based, etc.

ive started a few games and i can say from experience that you dont start on the same environment every time so you have to modify your strategy a little each time you play.. there are some scripted moments that dont change.. but beyond that you can have a different experience each time you play the game.

the above mode, along with all the improvements like tech/spell trees, etc is enough for me to recommend Warlock II.

a few criticisms:

the units seem kind of useless for the most part.  you have many summoning spells available to you, and what you get can be quite powerful.  especially the dragons and spirit wolves.  also, you will get 4 heroes as you progress through exiled mode which can also become quite deadly.  you use those 4 heroes, a high level summoned dragon and maybe a unit or two for good measure and you are pretty much set.  yes, you need to defend your cities as you play.. but honestly, once you reach the optimal city limit, which you can usually manage on two continents.. the cities can become expendable.

also, sometimes the random monster encounters you get can become frustrating.  they always seem to happen right around the time you are fighting a rival great mage.  some may consider this a positive.  myself, i just find it tedious.

one final minor criticism.. the diplomacy mechanic.  there really isnt one.  lets say you declare a seize fire on a rival so you can clear out some monsters.  its almost a guarantee that the AI will attack again real soon, sometimes even on the very next turn.  basically diplomacy comes down to  accepting the seize fire to get a spell, gold, and mana and thats about it.

conclusion:

IMO, the amount of content in the game is enough to consider it worth the price - whether you consider it an expansion or not.. ask yourself, in the end, is it worth $30.  me.  i say DEFINITELY.

reviewText: Have you played Civilization and mostly enjoyed the experience?  Did you ever want something that was a less involved in juggling the requirements of building a long term successful civilization and at the same time gave you the feeling of building an expanding empire?  Oh, and did you ever ponder what Civilization 5 would be like if it didn't take itself so serious?  Well, that pretty much sums up Warlock 2.  The comparison is unavoidable between the two since much of the interface is similar.  Much of what you do in the game will be familiar to Civ 5 players, just less involved and deep in its potential.  Diplomacy - check.  City building and development - check. Resource management - check.  Build troops to decimate the enemy - check.  Now, with all that said, the one area where Warlock 2 is possibly ahead of Civ 5 is the actual combat game.  Between the variety of combat types, upgrades, and magic types vs melee and ranged troops Warlock 5 shows itself to be more designed to be a pure combat empire builder than Civ 5.  Sure there are other types of victory conditions, but in the end most will play to dominate the enemy on the field of battle since the other types of victory are not nearly as deep and satisfying.  At times there is even an RPG component to Warlock 2 that some may find appealing.  The joy in Warlock is that it presents a fun and playable game that doesn't take itself too serious and at times even manages to laugh at itself.  For those that prefer there is a campaign game that unfold a story along with a more scripted gameplay, but for myself it is best as a sandbox where you can dapple in all the absurdity of a fantasy world inhabited with giant rats, vampires, and creatures normally found in mythology.

reviewText:
Warlock 2 and Its predesesor, Warlock Master of the Arcane, are among the best games that I have played on any platform. Having logged inumerabe hours in Civilization, the granddaddy of turn based strategy games, I actualy tjhink I prefer Warlock. Perhaps it is because the units in Warlock have more personality, thus I feel more emotionally invested in them.
A couple things  that I love about Warlock...
1. The controls are silky smooth and emipire management is simple and easy to deal wiith compared to any other TBS game I think of. Each turn icons representing different types of actions cascade down the right side of your screen- at least that is what they did in Master of the Arcane. In Warlolck 2 you have to expand a single action button to see the colulmn of icons- I prefer the icons in the previous game. In any event, management of your cities and units is quick and efficient- you are prompted to make decisions so there is no reason you will forget something important, allowing  to concentrate on strategy. Battles are on the campaign hex map and not on a separate battle screen.
2. The random map generator does a great job of changing things up. As in CIV you set the parameters, and the random geography created will have a huge impact on gameplay. Thus each camapign feels unique and replayability is thru the roof.

Comparing Warlork 2 to Warlock Master of the Arcane, they are virtually the same game with a couple races added, some new rules and options. They also added a spell tech tree which is an improvement. Master of the Arcane DLC was inexpensive and greatly enhanced the Warlock experience- the Dremor DLC was mind blowingly challenging, but I was up for the challenge- so I will expect the same from Warlock 2. Yes! Warlock 2 is worth the $30 price tag. How could I think not since it is one of my favorite games ever?

reviewText:
If you haven't played Warlock before, it's a Civilizations-style 4X strategy game set in a fantasy world, streamlined to require less micromanagement than Civ, but with a healthy dose of wild, interesting monsters and extra worlds in each game to place emphasis on exploration and colonization over internal economic management.  In my opinion, it plays faster than Civ at the expense of some depth, but makes up for that depth with rich, large worlds and a wide range of gameplay options on the combat level.

If you have played Warlock before, then Warlock 2 is pretty much exactly what you want in a sequel.  The Exile campaign mode sets players on exterior shards in a labyrinthine web of interesting miniature worlds to fight your way to the central hub world and beat the AI-controlled boss for control - which is interesting and compelling, if surprisingly difficult.  The new worlds add a wide variety of resources, monsters, and terrain to the game, which was not lacking in the first game but is a welcome addition.  Furthermore, the number of playable races has practically doubled, offering a great deal of replay value and a ton of new options for tech trees and internal management as you expand your empire to include a wider variety of creatures and troops.

On the downside, the game discourages vast empires with a city limit - which does prevent turns from going too long - but that option can be turned off on the menu.  Resources for creature upgrades are now limited to a set number of uses per resource, but that works as an incentive to do more exploration and expansion.  On the truly minor gripe level, the achievements are a bit glitchy at time of writing, but I suspect they'll be repaired in due time.

In short, Warlock 2 is a solid improvement on the already-solid Warlock formula.  If you're a Warlock fan, you should absolutely make the investment; if you're a Civilizations fan or a strategy fan, you should definitely try it out.

reviewText:
Warlock II: The Exiled is the kind of game that I should have written a review for a while ago, but because of the size of the game, and the VERY slow pace the game takes, I am now finally able to write up a review. First off this is a fantasy turn based adventure game where you are going to play the part of a powerful warlock who saved all the realms, but in his absence from the main realm became exiled. You will now have to gather troops, heroes, knowledge, and more if you are going to be able to retake what is rightfully your's. There will be many portals you will have to transverse, but if you can make it out to the other side you might just find your chance to exact your revenge.

Graphically this game is not going to blow you away, but at the same time it looks well done. I do like the concept that every realm is a floating island, and that there is a wide variety of lands that you will have to deal with. You might be dealing with snowy lands, deserts, lava, cursed lands, and water. You never know what the next world will bring. There's also a very wide variety of enemies to face off against, you will get the chance to battle sea serpents, minotaurs, elementals, dragons, bats, and more. The one thing that I wish had a little bit more TLC to it was the city screens. I understand that there was definitely a minimal approach to it, but it doesn't feel as polished.

The music does a great job of blending into the game to the point that you don't really notice it after a while.

The controls are pretty straight forward, you are going to be using the mouse almost exclusively, with the exception of WASD when you are playing on dual monitors. If you don't you will notice that you are constantly clicking out of the game when trying to scroll across the map.

Even though there is a story to follow, most of the game is randomly generated and is customized to the experience you want to have. You can choose the size of the land masses, the number of warlocks you will have to deal with, and of course the difficulty. Now I will say this, no matter what you are going to have to deal with micro-managing of resources until you can't take it any more. This game hinges on the fact that it plods along slowly so if there were issues you wouldn't see them. There's also a large amount of randomly generated neutral enemies that will pop back up after a while to keep you on your toes in areas that you have removed all your troops from. Speaking of troops, it is damn near impossible to be able to successfully sustain more than a handful of troops. The cost of gold, food, and mana per turn for each unit, hero, building, it will drive you made. There were only a very few times in the game where I was actually gaining on all 3 and that was when I didn't do anything on those turns. The one thing that did completely drive me up the wall was the fact that you have a limited amount of towns that you are allowed to have, and out of those you can only change the ones that you personally settled to specialty towns to help with your micro-managing and decrease your town count. Here's the problem, I'm a conquerer, I never built a second town, I've capture all the cities I've found, and yet I get penalized for it.

At the end of the day the thing about this game that you are going to NEED to have is the editor. This is probably one of the best and most in-depth editors I've seen in a long time. You can build an entire game out of it utilizing Warlock II as a backbone. If you are willing to put in the time you can EASILY make something light years better than what comes out of the box. So with that I have to give a grade on the game, as is, and not what the game can potentially have with user contributions. This game gets a 6.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
Warlock 2 is one of those games where I want to like it, and every time I play it I wish it was better. While this game has many qualities that I like, there are many things about it I do not. I will skip the nonsense and go straight to the pros and cons.

Pros:
*There are many game settings you can choose from in the sandbox mode, which is great for giving you just the right amount of a challenge.
*The game has a nice selection of characters to choose from. Each one very customizable, and many different races to choose as a starting city.
*The variety of units and enemies are very expansive. I never felt like every other race was just a clone of another.
*The game has a large amount of replayability. The above mentioned items, as well as completely random worlds and situations make each session unique.

Cons:
*For many users, this game encounters random crashes with no warnings or crash screen to explain what happened.
*The AI is extremely annoying. Almost every single game I play, the opponents constantly bug me for non-aggression pacts and alliances every 2 or 3 turns. I got to one point in a game where I met all 8 of them, and every 2 or 3 turns, all 8 of them asked for an alliance. You almost have to declare war on them just to make them shut up. But then they just ask for peace every few turns. This does not change based on difficulty.
*It is too easy to steamroll enemies. Honestly the most challenging parts of the game I have found to be exploring the other worlds with extremely hard wild monsters. Even on the max difficulty though, once you build up to it, you can just mow through every faction with little to no resistance. Their combat AI is no better than their diplomacy AI.

Other than that though, the game really has some potential. If someone out there was good with code, and could mod it to have a decent AI, I would recommend this game in a heartbeat. Or if the developer ever desires to finish what could have been an amazing game. As it stands though, I do not recommend it. At least not at full price. Wait for a Steam sale, and if you are dying for some new 4x, give it a shot.

reviewText:
TLDR: If you liked #1, this is an even better game. :-)

After finishing my first campaign, I found it to be quite a bit of fun.
My campaign of conquest was to return and overthrow the united one.
What I'd expected before I got there, was a huge map at the end, much like the starting map in Warlock 1, through which I'd have to fight a campaign of attrition against a heavily entrenched enemy, with many cities.

Imagine my surprise when I pop in and it's just another small world, with a few great mages now acting as just a few high level heros.
Because of this, the ending was rather short and anti-climactic.

Overall I found the spellbook to be a nice improvement over the previous, completely random one.
I like being able to see what is available and go for a specific thing in the long run.
This both reduced the time before I got useful spells and gave me a better feel of control of my guys magic.
I was happy to see my favorite area of Summoning to be expanded both in basic spells and in divine ones.
I was surprised you could now get dragon & elementals both as summons and city build units.

The game was stable throughout and did not crash or freeze once, unlike Warlock 1, which would randomly just sort of get stuck during a great mage turn... which happened every fifth game, it seemed.


The only bad thing about this which I can think of is that shadow bats are half of what pops up in the randomly generated lairs, which are generated at regular intervals; These units are WAY to powerful to be frequent popup units!

reviewText:
Warlock 2 is a confused 4x game which has broken the playfield up into a series of small maps connected via portals which you must cross to defeat the final opponent.  Nearing the portals with a unit triggers random events for activating the portal and other allies of the end boss will create random events of their own to trip you up.

Resource management is very strict.  It may be difficult at first to balance your cities so that they are able to grow and remain happy.  The number of cities you are able to control at a time is also kept very low (5-11 as the game progresses).  Although this can be changed with an option in the game settings it is marked 'Not Recommended'.  Developing advanced units can also be challenging as each is produced by a specific building which has other buildings as a pre-requisite and each building must be placed within a limited area in which other structures for wealth and food must also exist.  This forces the player along rather narrow paths which greatly limit the viable choices that can be made.

This is my main complaint about the game.  It feels too rigid.  The player is locked into a very limited set of choices while forced to face randomly appearing enemies and AI opponents which greatly outmatch you at every step.  This creates gameplay in which there is perhaps only one narrow path to victory and only by discovering that single formula can the player succeed.  This is in opposition to the general appeal of a 4x game which to me is that you can discover many paths to victory.

reviewText:
After playing Warlock and enjoying it, in spite of some niggling issues, I looked forward to trying Warlock 2. Anticipating new features, cleanups of quirks, and hopefully expanded content, I purchased and began playing. At first things looked good, however, after getting further into the game I quickly encountered several issues that caused me to throw my hands up and remove the game from my system. To whit:

Building buffs (like unit armor, combat training, resistance potions) are now limited to a very small quantity. For example, i was only able to outfit 5 units with basic armor. So once equipting my 4 heroes, I had to pick one lucky unit to get the last set.

Random monsters that spawn quite a bit more frequently than before (on default setting) now include creature types like shadow dragons, units with 300 hp, immune to a variety of usual attacks, and flying. So much for several of my cities.

After building up what seemed like a decent force of heroes, strong (100+ hp melee units) and ranged units (casters and archers), I daintly sent my forces into an outer plane. The horde of shadow dragons, deadwood elementals, gold dragons, and evil warlocks promptly showed me the error of my ways. And this was on the easiest difficulty level.

While the gameplay has indeed improved, it feels like the AI was improved by the use of power boosts rather than intelligence. I am not a big fan of 'meatgrinder' type campaigns, especially after the game was modified to restrict me to 5 starting cities (bumpable to 8). I simply could not generate enough quailty units fast enough to replace lost units.

If you appreciate running a constant stream of units to be killed while trying to achieve your goal, this game could certainly hold your interest. It does not appeal to me in that it pretty much makes the leveling, buffing, and equipting I prefer in building a fighting force completely moot.
